dn25:0.2.eng: The Lion’s Roar at the Monastery of Lady Udumbarikā

dn25:1.0.eng: 1. The Story of the Wanderer Nigrodha

dn25:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
dn25:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

dn25:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigrodho paribbājako udumbarikāya paribbājakārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṃ tiṃsamattehi paribbājakasatehi.
dn25:1.3.eng: Now at that time the wanderer Nigrodha was residing in the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers, together with a large assembly of three thousand wanderers.
dn25:1.3.comm: The Buddha refers to the events of this sutta at DN 8:23.2, but apart from that Nigrodha (“Banyan”) appears to be unknown. A “wanderer” may or may not be Brahmanical, but in DN 8 Nigrodha is called tapabrahmacārī, which suggests he was a celibate student of a Brahmanical teacher. | The commentary describes udumbarikā (“Fig”) as devī (“Queen”), while DA 8 says she is a “brahmin lady”. She too does not seem to appear elsewhere.

dn25:1.4.pli: Atha kho sandhāno gahapati divā divassa rājagahā nikkhami bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
dn25:1.4.eng: Then the householder Sandhāna left Rājagaha in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.
dn25:1.4.comm: Sandhāna (“Conciliation”) was recognized as an eminent lay follower at (AN 6.120–139:1.14).

dn25:1.6.eng: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,

dn25:1.8.eng: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,

dn25:1.10.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena udumbarikāya paribbājakārāmo, yena nigrodho paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
dn25:1.10.eng: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Nigrodha at the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers?”

dn25:1.11.pli: Atha kho sandhāno gahapati yena udumbarikāya paribbājakārāmo, tenupasaṅkami.
dn25:1.11.eng: So he went to the monastery of the wanderers.

dn25:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigrodho paribbājako mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṃ nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentiyā.
dn25:2.1.eng: Now at that time, Nigrodha was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a colossal racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as

dn25:2.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ itthikathaṃ sūrakathaṃ visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ pubbapetakathaṃ nānattakathaṃ lokakkhāyikaṃ samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ iti vā.
dn25:2.2.eng: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.

dn25:3.1.pli: Addasā kho nigrodho paribbājako sandhānaṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
dn25:3.1.eng: Nigrodha saw Sandhāna coming off in the distance,

dn25:3.3.eng: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.

dn25:3.4.pli: Ayaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako āgacchati sandhāno gahapati.
dn25:3.4.eng: The householder Sandhāna, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming.

dn25:3.5.pli: Yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā rājagahe paṭivasanti, ayaṃ tesaṃ aññataro sandhāno gahapati.
dn25:3.5.eng: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Rājagaha.

dn25:3.6.pli: Appasaddakāmā kho panete āyasmanto appasaddavinītā, appasaddassa vaṇṇavādino.
dn25:3.6.eng: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.

dn25:3.7.pli: Appeva nāma appasaddaṃ parisaṃ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
dn25:3.7.eng: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”

dn25:3.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.

dn25:4.1.pli: Atha kho sandhāno gahapati yena nigrodho paribbājako tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā nigrodhena paribbājakena saddhiṃ sammodi.
dn25:4.1.eng: Then Sandhāna went up to the wanderer Nigrodha, and exchanged greetings with him.

dn25:4.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sandhāno gahapati nigrodhaṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
dn25:4.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Nigrodha,

dn25:4.3.pli: “aññathā kho ime bhonto aññatitthiyā paribbājakā saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti.
dn25:4.3.eng: “The way the wanderers make an uproar as they sit together and talk about all kinds of low topics is one thing.

dn25:4.5.pli: Aññathā kho pana so bhagavā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppānī”ti.
dn25:4.5.eng: It’s quite different to the way the Buddha frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.”

dn25:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako sandhānaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
dn25:5.1.eng: When Sandhāna said this, Nigrodha said to him,

dn25:5.2.pli: “yagghe, gahapati, jāneyyāsi, kena samaṇo gotamo saddhiṃ sallapati, kena sākacchaṃ samāpajjati, kena paññāveyyattiyaṃ samāpajjati?
dn25:5.2.eng: “Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?

dn25:5.3.pli: Suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṃ sallāpāya.
dn25:5.3.eng: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion.

dn25:5.4.eng: He just lurks on the periphery.

dn25:5.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.
dn25:5.5.eng: He’s just like a one-eyed cow, circling around and lurking on the periphery.

dn25:5.10.pli: Iṅgha, gahapati, samaṇo gotamo imaṃ parisaṃ āgaccheyya, ekapañheneva naṃ saṃsādeyyāma, tucchakumbhīva naṃ maññe orodheyyāmā”ti.
dn25:5.10.eng: Go on, householder! Were the ascetic Gotama to come to this assembly, I’d sink him with just one question! I’d tie him up like a hollow pot!”
dn25:5.10.comm: Orodheyyāma normally means “enclose, trap” like ox in a pen (AN 6.60:3.1), but here it is glossed in the commentary as vinandheyyāma (“twist around”).

dn25:6.1.pli: Assosi kho bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya sandhānassa gahapatissa nigrodhena paribbājakena saddhiṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ.
dn25:6.1.eng: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard this discussion between the householder Sandhāna and the wanderer Nigrodha.

dn25:6.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohitvā yena sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkami.
dn25:6.2.eng: Then the Buddha descended from Vulture’s Peak Mountain and went to the peacocks’ feeding ground on the bank of the Sumāgadhā, where he walked mindfully in the open air.

dn25:6.3.pli: Addasā kho nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkamantaṃ.

dn25:6.5.pli: “appasaddā bhonto hontu, mā bhonto saddamakattha, ayaṃ samaṇo gotamo sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkamati.
dn25:6.5.eng: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound. The ascetic Gotama is walking mindfully on the bank of the Sumāgadhā.

dn25:6.6.pli: Appasaddakāmo kho pana so āyasmā, appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī.
dn25:6.6.eng: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.

dn25:6.7.pli: Appeva nāma appasaddaṃ parisaṃ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyya.
dn25:6.7.eng: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.

dn25:6.8.pli: Sace samaṇo gotamo imaṃ parisaṃ āgaccheyya, imaṃ taṃ pañhaṃ puccheyyāma:
dn25:6.8.eng: If he comes, I’ll ask him this question:

dn25:6.9.pli: ‘ko nāma so, bhante, bhagavato dhammo, yena bhagavā sāvake vineti, yena bhagavatā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyan’”ti?
dn25:6.9.eng: ‘Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?’”

dn25:6.10.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.

dn25:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena nigrodho paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
dn25:7.1.eng: Then the Buddha went up to the wanderer Nigrodha,

dn25:7.2.pli: Atha kho nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn25:7.3.pli: “etu kho, bhante, bhagavā, svāgataṃ, bhante, bhagavato.
dn25:7.3.eng: “Let the Blessed One come, sir! Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!

dn25:7.4.pli: Cirassaṃ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṃ idhāgamanāya.
dn25:7.4.eng: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

dn25:7.5.eng: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”

dn25:7.6.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,

dn25:7.7.pli: Nigrodhopi kho paribbājako aññataraṃ nīcāsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn25:7.7.eng: while Nigrodha took a low seat and sat to one side.

dn25:7.8.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho nigrodhaṃ paribbājakaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

dn25:7.9.pli: “kāya nuttha, nigrodha, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
dn25:7.9.eng: “Nigrodha, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
dn25:7.9.comm: This discourse highlights the Buddha’s method of engaging with people of other religions. He is open-hearted and interested in their views. He prefers to build on common ground, but is not afraid to criticize when it is warranted. And his aim is not to win converts, but to help people be free of suffering.

dn25:7.10.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn25:7.11.pli: “idha mayaṃ, bhante, addasāma bhagavantaṃ sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkamantaṃ, disvāna evaṃ avocumhā:
dn25:7.11.eng: “Well, sir, I saw you walking mindfully and said:

dn25:7.12.pli: ‘sace samaṇo gotamo imaṃ parisaṃ āgaccheyya, imaṃ taṃ pañhaṃ puccheyyāma:
dn25:7.12.eng: ‘If the ascetic Gotama comes, I’ll ask him this question:

dn25:7.13.pli: “ko nāma so, bhante, bhagavato dhammo, yena bhagavā sāvake vineti, yena bhagavatā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyan”’ti?
dn25:7.13.eng: “Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?”’

dn25:7.14.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā; atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
dn25:7.14.eng: This is the conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”

dn25:7.15.pli: “Dujjānaṃ kho etaṃ, nigrodha, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena, yenāhaṃ sāvake vinemi, yena mayā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyaṃ.
dn25:7.15.eng: “It’s hard for you to understand this, Nigrodha, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition.

dn25:7.16.pli: Iṅgha tvaṃ maṃ, nigrodha, sake ācariyake adhijegucche pañhaṃ puccha:
dn25:7.16.eng: Please ask me a question about the higher disgust of sin in your own tradition:
dn25:7.16.comm: “Higher disgust of sin” renders adhijegucche. The idea is that people are tainted with corruption, somewhat comparable to the notion of “original sin”, although due to their own actions in the past rather than ancestral legacy. In “disgust” at that sin, they practice forms of fervent mortification (tapas) to burn out the corruption.

dn25:7.17.pli: ‘kathaṃ santā nu kho, bhante, tapojigucchā paripuṇṇā hoti, kathaṃ aparipuṇṇā’”ti?
dn25:7.17.eng: ‘How are the conditions for the fervent mortification in disgust of sin completed, and how are they incomplete?’”
dn25:7.17.comm: The phrase kathaṁ santā is unique; it echoes evaṁ sante below.

dn25:7.18.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te paribbājakā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṃ:
dn25:7.18.eng: When he said this, those wanderers made an uproar,

dn25:7.19.pli: “acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, samaṇassa gotamassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā, yatra hi nāma sakavādaṃ ṭhapessati, paravādena pavāressatī”ti.
dn25:7.19.eng: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The ascetic Gotama has such power and might! For he sets aside his own doctrine and invites discussion on the doctrine of others!”

dn25:8.1.pli: Atha kho nigrodho paribbājako te paribbājake appasadde katvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn25:8.1.eng: Then Nigrodha, having quieted those wanderers, said to the Buddha,

dn25:8.2.pli: “mayaṃ kho, bhante, tapojigucchāvādā tapojigucchāsārā tapojigucchāallīnā viharāma.
dn25:8.2.eng: “Sir, we teach fervent mortification in disgust of sin, regarding it as essential and sticking to it.

dn25:8.3.pli: Kathaṃ santā nu kho, bhante, tapojigucchā paripuṇṇā hoti, kathaṃ aparipuṇṇā”ti?
dn25:8.3.eng: How are the conditions for the fervent mortification in disgust of sin completed, and how are they incomplete?”

dn25:8.4.pli: “Idha, nigrodha, tapassī acelako hoti muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano, naehibhaddantiko, natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṃ, na uddissakataṃ, na nimantanaṃ sādiyati,
dn25:8.4.eng: “Nigrodha, it’s when a mortifier goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
dn25:8.4.comm: See the passage at DN 8:14.3 and notes thereto.

dn25:8.5.pli: so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṃ, na daṇḍamantaraṃ, na musalamantaraṃ, na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṃ, na maṃsaṃ, na suraṃ, na merayaṃ, na thusodakaṃ pivati,
dn25:8.5.eng: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breast-feeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.

dn25:8.6.pli: so ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko, sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko, ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti, sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
dn25:8.6.eng: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

dn25:8.7.pli: ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
dn25:8.7.eng: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.

dn25:8.8.pli: So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti; vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
dn25:8.8.eng: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

dn25:8.9.pli: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṃsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti,
dn25:8.9.eng: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.

dn25:8.10.eng: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

dn25:8.11.eng: They constantly stand, turning down seats.

dn25:8.12.eng: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.

dn25:8.13.eng: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.

dn25:8.14.eng: They make their bed on a plank, or the bare ground.

dn25:8.15.eng: They lie only on one side.

dn25:8.17.eng: They stay in the open air.

dn25:8.18.eng: They sleep wherever they lay their mat.

dn25:8.19.eng: They eat unnatural things, committed to the practice of eating unnatural foods.

dn25:8.20.eng: They don’t drink, committed to the practice of not drinking liquids.

dn25:8.21.eng: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.

dn25:8.23.pli: yadi evaṃ sante tapojigucchā paripuṇṇā vā hoti aparipuṇṇā vā”ti?
dn25:8.23.eng: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin complete, or incomplete?”

dn25:8.24.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tapojigucchā paripuṇṇā hoti, no aparipuṇṇā”ti.
dn25:8.24.eng: “Clearly, sir, if that is so the fervent mortification in disgust of sin is complete, not incomplete.”

dn25:8.25.pli: “Evaṃ paripuṇṇāyapi kho ahaṃ, nigrodha, tapojigucchāya anekavihite upakkilese vadāmī”ti.
dn25:8.25.eng: “But even such a completed mortification has many defects, I say.”

dn25:9.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā evaṃ paripuṇṇāya tapojigucchāya anekavihite upakkilese vadatī”ti?
dn25:9.1.eng: “But how does the Buddha say that even such a completed mortification has many defects?”

dn25:9.2.pli: “Idha, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
dn25:9.2.eng: “Firstly, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for.
dn25:9.2.comm: The Buddha shifts attention from the external practice to the psychological state that accompanies it.

dn25:9.3.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

dn25:9.4.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:9.4.eng: This is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:9.5.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā attānukkaṃseti paraṃ vambheti.
dn25:9.5.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

dn25:9.6.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā attānukkaṃseti paraṃ vambheti.

dn25:9.7.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:9.7.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:9.8.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā majjati mucchati pamādamāpajjati.
dn25:9.8.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They become indulgent and infatuated and fall into negligence on account of that.

dn25:9.9.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā majjati mucchati pamādamāpajjati.

dn25:9.10.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:9.10.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
dn25:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for.

dn25:10.2.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

dn25:10.3.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:10.3.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:10.4.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena attānukkaṃseti paraṃ vambheti.
dn25:10.4.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

dn25:10.5.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena attānukkaṃseti paraṃ vambheti.

dn25:10.6.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:10.6.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:10.7.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati mucchati pamādamāpajjati.
dn25:10.7.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They generate possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification. They become indulgent and infatuated and fall into negligence on account of that.

dn25:10.8.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati mucchati pamādamāpajjati.

dn25:10.9.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:10.9.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:10.10.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī bhojanesu vodāsaṃ āpajjati:
dn25:10.10.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier becomes fussy about food, saying,

dn25:10.11.eng: ‘This is acceptable to me, this is not acceptable to me.’

dn25:10.12.pli: So yañca khvassa nakkhamati, taṃ sāpekkho pajahati.
dn25:10.12.eng: What is not acceptable they give up in expectation.
dn25:10.12.comm: “In expectation” (sāpekkho): when they give up something they cannot eat, they expect to be given more suitable food.

dn25:10.13.pli: Yaṃ panassa khamati, taṃ gadhito mucchito ajjhāpanno anādīnavadassāvī anissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati …pe…
dn25:10.13.eng: But what is acceptable they eat tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.

dn25:10.14.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:10.14.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:10.15.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati lābhasakkārasilokanikantihetu:
dn25:10.15.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity, thinking,

dn25:10.16.pli: ‘sakkarissanti maṃ rājāno rājamahāmattā khattiyā brāhmaṇā gahapatikā titthiyā’ti …pe…
dn25:10.16.eng: ‘Kings, royal ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and sectarians will honor me!’

dn25:10.17.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:10.17.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī aññataraṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā apasādetā hoti:
dn25:11.1.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier rebukes a certain ascetic or brahmin,

dn25:11.2.eng: ‘What is it with this one living in abundance, devouring everything—

dn25:11.3.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ, asanivicakkaṃ dantakūṭaṃ, samaṇappavādenā’ti …pe…
dn25:11.3.eng: plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. According to this ascetic’s doctrine, the crown of the tooth is forked lightning!’
dn25:11.3.comm: Asanivicakkaṁ is “forked lightning”, see Rig Veda 4.35.2 where vicakra means “divided”. | Dantakūṭa is “the crown of the tooth”.

dn25:11.4.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:11.4.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:11.5.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī passati aññataraṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā kulesu sakkariyamānaṃ garukariyamānaṃ māniyamānaṃ pūjiyamānaṃ.
dn25:11.5.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier sees a certain ascetic or brahmin being honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.

dn25:11.7.pli: ‘imañhi nāma sambahulājīvaṃ kulesu sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti.
dn25:11.7.eng: ‘This one, who lives in abundance, is honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.

dn25:11.8.pli: Maṃ pana tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ kulesu na sakkaronti na garuṃ karonti na mānenti na pūjentī’ti, iti so issāmacchariyaṃ kulesu uppādetā hoti …pe…
dn25:11.8.eng: But I, a fervent mortifier who lives rough, am not honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated among good families.’ Thus they give rise to jealousy and stinginess regarding families.

dn25:11.9.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:11.9.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:11.10.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī āpāthakanisādī hoti …pe…
dn25:11.10.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier sits meditation only when people can see them.

dn25:11.11.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:11.11.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:11.12.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī attānaṃ adassayamāno kulesu carati:
dn25:11.12.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier sneaks about among families, thinking,
dn25:11.12.comm: “Sneaks” is attānaṁ adassayamāno, literally, “not showing himself”. They like to hang about with lay folk, but hide the fact that they do so.

dn25:11.13.eng: ‘This is part of my mortification; this is part of my mortification.’

dn25:11.14.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:11.14.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:11.15.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī kiñcideva paṭicchannaṃ sevati.
dn25:11.15.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier sometimes behaves in an underhand manner.

dn25:11.16.pli: So ‘khamati te idan’ti puṭṭho samāno akkhamamānaṃ āha: ‘khamatī’ti.
dn25:11.16.eng: When asked whether something is acceptable to them, they say it is, even though it isn’t.

dn25:11.17.eng: Or they say it isn’t, even though it is.

dn25:11.18.eng: Thus they tell a deliberate lie.

dn25:11.19.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:11.19.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tathāgatassa vā tathāgatasāvakassa vā dhammaṃ desentassa santaṃyeva pariyāyaṃ anuññeyyaṃ nānujānāti …pe…
dn25:12.1.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier disagrees with the way that the Realized One or their disciple teaches Dhamma, even when they make a valid point.

dn25:12.2.pli: ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:12.2.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:12.3.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī kodhano hoti upanāhī.
dn25:12.3.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier is irritable and acrimonious …

dn25:12.4.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī kodhano hoti upanāhī.

dn25:12.5.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.

dn25:12.6.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī makkhī hoti paḷāsī …pe…

dn25:12.10.pli: pāpiccho hoti pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gato …
dn25:12.10.eng: they have corrupt wishes, falling under the sway of corrupt wishes …

dn25:12.11.eng: they have wrong view, being attached to an extremist view …

dn25:12.12.eng: they’re attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
dn25:12.12.comm: As here, this item typically follows “wrong view”. At AN 10.78:1.9 it is said to be a bad quality of Jain ascetics. Thus being “attached to one’s own views” refers both to the subjective clinging as well as the objective incorrectness of the views.

dn25:12.13.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī.

dn25:12.14.pli: Ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.
dn25:12.14.eng: This too is a defect in that mortifier.

dn25:12.16.pli: yadime tapojigucchā upakkilesā vā anupakkilesā vā”ti?
dn25:12.16.eng: Are such mortifications defective or not?”

dn25:12.17.pli: “Addhā kho ime, bhante, tapojigucchā upakkilesā, no anupakkilesā.

dn25:12.18.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhante, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco tapassī sabbeheva imehi upakkilesehi samannāgato assa;
dn25:12.18.eng: It’s possible that a mortifier might have all of these defects,

dn25:12.19.eng: let alone one or other of them.”

dn25:13.1.pli: “Idha, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
dn25:13.1.eng: “Firstly, Nigrodha, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. But they’re not happy with that, as they still haven’t got all they wished for.

dn25:13.2.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

dn25:13.3.pli: Evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.

dn25:13.4.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā na attānukkaṃseti na paraṃ vambheti …pe…

dn25:13.9.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.

dn25:13.10.eng: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of possessions, honor, and popularity …

dn25:13.11.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.

dn25:13.12.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṃ samādiyati, so tena tapasā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti, so tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati na mucchati na pamādamāpajjati …pe…

dn25:13.13.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.

dn25:13.17.pli: Yaṃ panassa khamati, taṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati …pe…
dn25:13.17.eng: But what is acceptable they eat without being tied, infatuated, attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.

dn25:13.18.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
dn25:13.18.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:13.19.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī na tapaṃ samādiyati lābhasakkārasilokanikantihetu:
dn25:13.19.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t undertake a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity …

dn25:13.20.pli: ‘sakkarissanti maṃ rājāno rājamahāmattā khattiyā brāhmaṇā gahapatikā titthiyā’ti …pe…
dn25:13.20.eng: ‘Kings, royal ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and sectarians will honor me!’

dn25:13.21.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
dn25:13.21.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:13.22.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī aññataraṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā nāpasādetā hoti:
dn25:13.22.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t rebuke a certain ascetic or brahmin,

dn25:13.24.eng: plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. According to this ascetic’s doctrine, the crown of the tooth is like forked lightning!’

dn25:13.25.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
dn25:13.25.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:14.7.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:14.8.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier doesn’t sneak about among families, thinking,

dn25:14.10.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:15.1.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier agrees with the way that the Realized One or their disciple teaches Dhamma when they make a valid point.

dn25:15.2.pli: evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
dn25:15.2.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:15.3.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī akkodhano hoti anupanāhī.
dn25:15.3.eng: Furthermore, a mortifier is not irritable and acrimonious …

dn25:15.4.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī akkodhano hoti anupanāhī evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.

dn25:15.5.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī amakkhī hoti apaḷāsī …pe…

dn25:15.9.pli: na pāpiccho hoti na pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gato …

dn25:15.10.pli: na micchādiṭṭhiko hoti na antaggāhikāya diṭṭhiyā samannāgato …

dn25:15.11.pli: na sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti na ādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī.
dn25:15.11.eng: they’re not attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.

dn25:15.12.pli: Yampi, nigrodha, tapassī na sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti na ādhānaggāhī suppaṭinissaggī.

dn25:15.13.pli: Evaṃ so tasmiṃ ṭhāne parisuddho hoti.
dn25:15.13.eng: So they’re pure on that point.

dn25:15.15.pli: yadi evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā vā hoti aparisuddhā vā”ti?
dn25:15.15.eng: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”

dn25:15.16.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
dn25:15.16.eng: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”

dn25:15.17.pli: “Na kho, nigrodha, ettāvatā tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca;
dn25:15.17.eng: “No, Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has not yet reached the peak and the pith.

dn25:15.18.eng: Rather, it has only reached the shoots.”

dn25:16.1.pli: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca?
dn25:16.1.eng: “But at what point, sir, does the fervent mortification in disgust of sin reach the peak and the pith?

dn25:16.2.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tapojigucchāya aggaññeva pāpetu, sāraññeva pāpetū”ti.
dn25:16.2.eng: Please help me reach the peak and the pith!”

dn25:16.3.eng: “Nigrodha, take a mortifier who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
dn25:16.3.comm: A “fourfold restraint” (cātuyāma, or cāujjāma in Jain Ardhamagadhi) is attributed to Jain founder Pārśva in Isibhāsiyāiṁ 31, where it is an abbreviated list: “from refraining from killing to refraining from possessions” (pāṇātivāta-veramaṇeṇaṁ jāvā pariggaha-veramaṇeṇaṁ); the missing items are not stealing (asteya) and truth (satya). The Jain text Uttarādhyayanasūtra 23 shows that Mahāvīra added nakedness to make five. Five are also found in Yogasūtra 2.30 and the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 7: non-harming (ahiṁsā), truth (satya), no stealing (asteya), celibacy (brahmacarya), and non-possessiveness (aparigrahā). | A different “fourfold restraint” is said to be a Jain practice at DN 2:29.2.

dn25:16.4.eng: And how is a mortifier restrained in the fourfold constraint?

dn25:16.5.pli: Idha, nigrodha, tapassī na pāṇaṃ atipāteti, na pāṇaṃ atipātayati, na pāṇamatipātayato samanuñño hoti.
dn25:16.5.eng: It’s when a mortifier doesn’t kill living creatures, doesn’t get others to kill, and doesn’t approve of killing.
dn25:16.5.comm: This extends the basic precept. The same analysis is applied to the “ten ways of performing deeds” at AN 3.163. | The distinction between one’s own action and another’s action is noted at Isibhāsiyāiṁ 31.42, although the wording and sense are different.

dn25:16.6.pli: Na adinnaṃ ādiyati, na adinnaṃ ādiyāpeti, na adinnaṃ ādiyato samanuñño hoti.
dn25:16.6.eng: They don’t steal, get others to steal, or approve of stealing.

dn25:16.7.pli: Na musā bhaṇati, na musā bhaṇāpeti, na musā bhaṇato samanuñño hoti.
dn25:16.7.eng: They don’t lie, get others to lie, or approve of lying.

dn25:16.8.pli: Na bhāvitamāsīsati, na bhāvitamāsīsāpeti, na bhāvitamāsīsato samanuñño hoti.
dn25:16.8.eng: They don’t expect rewards from their practice, they don’t lead others to expect rewards, and they don’t approve of expecting rewards.
dn25:16.8.comm: Bhāvitamāsīsati is unique. In this and similar contexts, the Pali tradition says bhāvita (“reward”, normally “developed”) is the “five sense pleasures” as they see it (bhāvitaṁ nāma tesaṁ saññāya pañca kāmaguṇā; cp. MN 56 commentary: ettha ca bhāvitanti pañcakāmaguṇā), explaining that this is a usage of the sectarians (Saddanīti ch. 4: titthiyasamaye pana bhāvitoti kāmaguṇo vuccati).

dn25:16.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, nigrodha, tapassī cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti.
dn25:16.9.eng: That’s how a mortifier is restrained in the fourfold constraint.

dn25:16.10.pli: Yato kho, nigrodha, tapassī cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti, aduṃ cassa hoti tapassitāya.
dn25:16.10.eng: When a mortifier is restrained in the fourfold constraint, that is their mortification.

dn25:16.11.eng: They step forward, not falling back.

dn25:16.12.pli: So vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
dn25:16.12.eng: They frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

dn25:16.13.pli: So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
dn25:16.13.eng: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.

dn25:16.14.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
dn25:16.14.eng: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.

dn25:16.15.pli: Byāpādappadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādappadosā cittaṃ parisodheti.
dn25:16.15.eng: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.

dn25:16.16.pli: Thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti.
dn25:16.16.eng: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

dn25:16.17.pli: Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti.
dn25:16.17.eng: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.

dn25:16.18.pli: Vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
dn25:16.18.eng: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

dn25:17.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
dn25:17.1.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

dn25:17.2.pli: mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṃ. Tathā tatiyaṃ. Tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
dn25:17.2.eng: Then they meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn25:17.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

dn25:17.4.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

dn25:17.5.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṃ. Tathā tatiyaṃ. Tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
dn25:17.5.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn25:17.7.pli: Yadi evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā vā hoti aparisuddhā vā”ti?
dn25:17.7.eng: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”

dn25:17.8.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
dn25:17.8.eng: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”

dn25:17.9.pli: “Na kho, nigrodha, ettāvatā tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca;
dn25:17.9.eng: “No, Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has not yet reached the peak and the pith.

dn25:17.10.eng: Rather, it has only reached the bark.”

dn25:18.1.pli: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca?
dn25:18.1.eng: “But at what point, sir, does the fervent mortification in disgust of sin reach the peak and the pith?

dn25:18.2.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tapojigucchāya aggaññeva pāpetu, sāraññeva pāpetū”ti.
dn25:18.2.eng: Please help me reach the peak and the pith!”

dn25:18.3.eng: “Nigrodha, take a mortifier who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.

dn25:18.5.pli: yato kho, nigrodha, tapassī cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti, aduṃ cassa hoti tapassitāya.

dn25:18.8.pli: so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
dn25:18.8.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

dn25:18.9.eng: Then they meditate spreading a heart full of love …

dn25:18.12.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.

dn25:18.13.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ, tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn25:18.13.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dn25:18.15.pli: yadi evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā vā hoti aparisuddhā vā”ti?
dn25:18.15.eng: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”

dn25:18.16.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti, no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
dn25:18.16.eng: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”

dn25:18.17.pli: “Na kho, nigrodha, ettāvatā tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca;
dn25:18.17.eng: “No, Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has not yet reached the peak and the pith.

dn25:18.18.eng: Rather, it has only reached the softwood.”

dn25:19.1.pli: “Kittāvatā pana, bhante, tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca?
dn25:19.1.eng: “But at what point, sir, does the fervent mortification in disgust of sin reach the peak and the pith?

dn25:19.2.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tapojigucchāya aggaññeva pāpetu, sāraññeva pāpetū”ti.
dn25:19.2.eng: Please help me reach the peak and the pith!”

dn25:19.3.eng: “Nigrodha, take a mortifier who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.

dn25:19.5.pli: yato kho, nigrodha, tapassī cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti, aduṃ cassa hoti tapassitāya.

dn25:19.8.pli: so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
dn25:19.8.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

dn25:19.9.eng: Then they meditate spreading a heart full of love …

dn25:19.10.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.

dn25:19.11.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn25:19.11.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dn25:19.12.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
dn25:19.12.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

dn25:19.14.pli: yadi evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā vā hoti aparisuddhā vā”ti?
dn25:19.14.eng: If this is so, is the fervent mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”

dn25:19.15.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
dn25:19.15.eng: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”

dn25:19.16.pli: “Ettāvatā kho, nigrodha, tapojigucchā aggappattā ca hoti sārappattā ca.
dn25:19.16.eng: “Nigrodha, at this point the fervent mortification in disgust of sin has reached the peak and the pith.

dn25:19.17.pli: Iti kho, nigrodha, yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ avacāsi:
dn25:19.17.eng: Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:

dn25:19.18.pli: ‘ko nāma so, bhante, bhagavato dhammo, yena bhagavā sāvake vineti, yena bhagavatā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyan’ti.
dn25:19.18.eng: ‘Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?’

dn25:19.19.pli: Iti kho taṃ, nigrodha, ṭhānaṃ uttaritarañca paṇītatarañca, yenāhaṃ sāvake vinemi, yena mayā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyan”ti.
dn25:19.19.eng: Well, there is something better and finer than this. That’s what I use to guide my disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.”

dn25:19.20.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te paribbājakā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṃ:
dn25:19.20.eng: When he said this, those wanderers made an uproar,

dn25:19.21.pli: “ettha mayaṃ anassāma sācariyakā, na mayaṃ ito bhiyyo uttaritaraṃ pajānāmā”ti.
dn25:19.21.eng: “In that case, we’re lost, and so is our tradition! We don’t know anything better or finer than that!”

dn25:20.2.pli: “aññadatthu kho dānime aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bhagavato bhāsitaṃ sussūsanti, sotaṃ odahanti, aññācittaṃ upaṭṭhāpentī”ti.
dn25:20.2.eng: “Obviously, now these wanderers want to listen to what the Buddha says. They’re actively listening and trying to understand!”

dn25:20.3.eng: So he said to the wanderer Nigrodha,

dn25:20.4.pli: “iti kho, bhante nigrodha, yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ avacāsi:
dn25:20.4.eng: “Honorable Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:

dn25:20.5.pli: ‘yagghe, gahapati, jāneyyāsi, kena samaṇo gotamo saddhiṃ sallapati, kena sākacchaṃ samāpajjati, kena paññāveyyattiyaṃ samāpajjati,
dn25:20.5.eng: ‘Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?

dn25:20.6.pli: suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā, aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṃ sallāpāya, so antamantāneva sevati;
dn25:20.6.eng: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion. He just lurks on the periphery.

dn25:20.7.pli: seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.
dn25:20.7.eng: He’s just like a one-eyed cow, circling around and lurking on the periphery.

dn25:20.8.pli: Evameva suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā, aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṃ sallāpāya; so antamantāneva sevati;

dn25:20.9.pli: iṅgha, gahapati, samaṇo gotamo imaṃ parisaṃ āgaccheyya, ekapañheneva naṃ saṃsādeyyāma, tucchakumbhīva naṃ maññe orodheyyāmā’ti.
dn25:20.9.eng: Please, householder, let the ascetic Gotama come to this assembly. I’ll sink him with just one question! I’ll roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot!’

dn25:20.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, bhante, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho idhānuppatto, aparisāvacaraṃ pana naṃ karotha, gokāṇaṃ pariyantacāriniṃ karotha, ekapañheneva naṃ saṃsādetha, tucchakumbhīva naṃ orodhethā”ti.
dn25:20.10.eng: Now the Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened, has arrived here. Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a one-eyed cow? Why don’t you sink him with just one question? Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?”

dn25:20.11.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako tuṇhībhūto maṅkubhūto pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno nisīdi.
dn25:20.11.eng: When he said this, Nigrodha sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

dn25:21.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nigrodhaṃ paribbājakaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ maṅkubhūtaṃ pattakkhandhaṃ adhomukhaṃ pajjhāyantaṃ appaṭibhānaṃ viditvā nigrodhaṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
dn25:21.1.eng: Knowing this, the Buddha said to him,

dn25:21.2.pli: “saccaṃ kira, nigrodha, bhāsitā te esā vācā”ti?
dn25:21.2.eng: “Is it really true, Nigrodha—are those your words?”

dn25:21.3.pli: “Saccaṃ, bhante, bhāsitā me esā vācā, yathābālena yathāmūḷhena yathāakusalenā”ti.
dn25:21.3.eng: “It’s true, sir, those are my words. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me.”

dn25:21.5.pli: Kinti te sutaṃ paribbājakānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
dn25:21.5.eng: Have you heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said that

dn25:21.6.pli: ‘ye te ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, evaṃ su te bhagavanto saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti.
dn25:21.6.eng: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they made an uproar, a colossal racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of low topics,

dn25:21.8.eng: like you do in your tradition these days?

dn25:21.9.pli: Udāhu, evaṃ su te bhagavanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, seyyathāpāhaṃ etarahī’”ti.
dn25:21.9.eng: Or did they say that the Buddhas frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat, like I do these days?”

dn25:21.10.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante. Paribbājakānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
dn25:21.10.eng: “I have heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, said that

dn25:21.11.pli: ‘ye te ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, na evaṃ su te bhagavanto saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti.
dn25:21.11.eng: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they didn’t make an uproar,

dn25:21.13.eng: like I do in my tradition these days.

dn25:21.14.pli: Evaṃ su te bhagavanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, seyyathāpi bhagavā etarahī’”ti.
dn25:21.14.eng: They said that the Buddhas of the past frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness, like the Buddha does these days.”

dn25:21.15.pli: “Tassa te, nigrodha, viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi:
dn25:21.15.eng: “Nigrodha, you are a sensible and mature man. Did it not occur to you:

dn25:21.16.pli: ‘buddho so bhagavā bodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, danto so bhagavā damathāya dhammaṃ deseti, santo so bhagavā samathāya dhammaṃ deseti, tiṇṇo so bhagavā taraṇāya dhammaṃ deseti, parinibbuto so bhagavā parinibbānāya dhammaṃ desetī’”ti?
dn25:21.16.eng: ‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and quenched. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, taming, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment’?”

dn25:22.0.eng: 5. The Culmination of the Spiritual Path

dn25:22.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn25:22.2.pli: “accayo maṃ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yvāhaṃ evaṃ bhagavantaṃ avacāsiṃ.
dn25:22.2.eng: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to speak in that way.

dn25:22.3.pli: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
dn25:22.3.eng: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”

dn25:22.4.pli: “Taggha tvaṃ, nigrodha, accayo accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yo maṃ tvaṃ evaṃ avacāsi.
dn25:22.4.eng: “Indeed, Nigrodha, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to speak in that way.

dn25:22.5.pli: Yato ca kho tvaṃ, nigrodha, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikarosi, taṃ te mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma.
dn25:22.5.eng: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

dn25:22.6.pli: Vuddhi hesā, nigrodha, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti āyatiṃ saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
dn25:22.6.eng: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.

dn25:22.7.pli: Ahaṃ kho pana, nigrodha, evaṃ vadāmi:
dn25:22.7.eng: Nigrodha, this is what I say:

dn25:22.8.pli: ‘Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
dn25:22.8.eng: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.

dn25:22.9.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati sattavassāni.
dn25:22.9.eng: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven years. They will live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn25:22.11.pli: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
dn25:22.11.eng: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.

dn25:22.12.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati cha vassāni.
dn25:22.12.eng: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in six years …

dn25:22.19.pli: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko ahamanusāsāmi ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.

dn25:22.20.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati satta māsāni.

dn25:22.30.pli: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
dn25:22.30.eng: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.

dn25:22.31.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati sattāhaṃ’.
dn25:22.31.eng: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven days.

dn25:23.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:

dn25:23.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants pupils.’

dn25:23.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, nigrodha, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
dn25:23.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

dn25:23.4.pli: Yo eva vo ācariyo, so eva vo ācariyo hotu.
dn25:23.4.eng: Let your tutor remain your tutor.
dn25:23.4.comm: This passage sets a powerful template for sincere engagement.

dn25:23.5.pli: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:

dn25:23.6.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our recitation.’

dn25:23.7.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, nigrodha, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
dn25:23.7.eng: But you should not see it like this.

dn25:23.8.pli: Yo eva vo uddeso so eva vo uddeso hotu.
dn25:23.8.eng: Let your recitation remain as it is.

dn25:23.9.pli: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:

dn25:23.10.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our livelihood.’

dn25:23.11.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, nigrodha, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
dn25:23.11.eng: But you should not see it like this.

dn25:23.12.pli: Yo eva vo ājīvo, so eva vo ājīvo hotu.
dn25:23.12.eng: Let your livelihood remain as it is.

dn25:23.13.pli: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:

dn25:23.14.pli: ‘ye no dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṃ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
dn25:23.14.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to start doing things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in our tradition.’

dn25:23.15.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, nigrodha, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
dn25:23.15.eng: But you should not see it like this.

dn25:23.16.pli: Akusalā ceva vo te dhammā hontu akusalasaṅkhātā ca sācariyakānaṃ.
dn25:23.16.eng: Let those things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in your tradition remain as they are.

dn25:23.17.pli: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:

dn25:23.18.pli: ‘ye no dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṃ, tehi vivecetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
dn25:23.18.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to stop doing things that are skillful and considered skillful in our tradition.’

dn25:23.19.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, nigrodha, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
dn25:23.19.eng: But you should not see it like this.

dn25:23.20.pli: Kusalā ceva vo te dhammā hontu kusalasaṅkhātā ca sācariyakānaṃ.
dn25:23.20.eng: Let those things that are skillful and considered skillful in your tradition remain as they are.

dn25:23.21.pli: Iti khvāhaṃ, nigrodha, neva antevāsikamyatā evaṃ vadāmi, napi uddesā cāvetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi, napi ājīvā cāvetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṃ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṃ, tehi vivecetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi.
dn25:23.21.eng: I do not speak for any of these reasons.

dn25:23.22.pli: Santi ca kho, nigrodha, akusalā dhammā appahīnā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, yesāhaṃ pahānāya dhammaṃ desemi.
dn25:23.22.eng: Nigrodha, there are things that are unskillful, corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. I teach Dhamma so that those things may be given up.

dn25:23.23.pli: Yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṅkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodānīyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
dn25:23.23.eng: When you practice accordingly, corrupting qualities will be given up in you and cleansing qualities will grow. You’ll enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with your own insight in this very life.”

dn25:24.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhībhūtā maṅkubhūtā pattakkhandhā adhomukhā pajjhāyantā appaṭibhānā nisīdiṃsu yathā taṃ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacittā.
dn25:24.1.eng: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, as if their minds were possessed by Māra.

dn25:24.2.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
dn25:24.2.comm: This whole ending sequence is unique.

dn25:24.3.eng: “All these silly people have been touched by the Wicked One!

dn25:24.4.pli: Yatra hi nāma ekassapi na evaṃ bhavissati:
dn25:24.4.eng: For not even a single one thinks,

dn25:24.5.pli: ‘handa mayaṃ aññāṇatthampi samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ carāma, kiṃ karissati sattāho’”ti?
dn25:24.5.eng: ‘Come, let us lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama for the sake of enlightenment—for what do seven days matter?’”

dn25:24.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā udumbarikāya paribbājakārāme sīhanādaṃ naditvā vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā gijjhakūṭe pabbate paccupaṭṭhāsi.
dn25:24.6.eng: Then the Buddha, having roared his lion’s roar in the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers, rose into the air and landed on Vulture’s Peak.

dn25:24.7.pli: Sandhāno pana gahapati tāvadeva rājagahaṃ pāvisīti.
dn25:24.7.eng: Meanwhile, the householder Sandhāna went right back to Rājagaha.
